transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: My name's Bond, James Bond.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: And that is Moore, Sir Roger Moore, playing the iconic British agent in "Live and Let Die," his first movie as Bond. Moore defined the dashing role in seven of the movies. Sir Roger, it is a great honor to have you in my studio, I must say.

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: Piers, very nice to see you again. But please, call me Roger.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: I can't. Americans wouldn't stand for it. Now, you appeared in seven of the Bond movies. And yet, I heard you in an interview earlier today saying that you felt "Skyfall," the new Daniel Craig movie, is the best Bond movie you have seen it.

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: Well, it is. Certainly the box office proves it in Europe. It is -- actually, I think what I said this morning was that I finished this book, "Bond on Bond," about four, five months ago. Before it went to press, I would have loved to have seen "Skyfall," because I would have put another chapter in.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: You thought it was really good?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: I think he is tremendous. And it's a great film. Wonderful director, Sam Mendes.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Let's watch a clip from "Skyfall." Here. He does a lot of his own stunts, apparently. You never did that, did you?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: I did a couple of the love scenes. Well, that's stunts (ph).

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: I always think with all the Bonds, Sean Connery would win a fight, if you all went into a bar and a big fight broke out, Sean Connery would probably be the hardest. I think that you, though, you would pull the most women. I think they would gravitate to that little twinkling, raised eyebrow.

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: I always said that Sean was a killer and I was a lover. But I now say that Daniel Craig is the real killer.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Of all the Bond girls, and there were so many, especially in the seven movies you made, if I could trap you on a desert island with one of them, and I know it is like choosing your favorite baby, but if I can put you on an island for the rest of your life with one Bond girl, who would it be?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: I'd actually go with my wife.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: That is a complete copout, Sir Roger. And you are only doing that because she's watching this.

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: She may not be watching it because I can make sure she doesn't.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Let me rephrase. If it was with your wife's permission --

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: If it was -- .

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Which I know is highly unlikely.

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: It would have to be one of the Swedish ladies, particularly like Maude Adams.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Really?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: I can say "I love you" in Swedish.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Being James Bond, there are two of the most exclusive boys clubs in the world. One is surviving, living presidents of the United States, there are five of them, and all six men who played Bond are still alive. You, Sean Connery, Daniel Craig, Timothy Dalton, Piers Brosnan, and the one everyone forgets, George Lazenby.

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: You call this a living?

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: What is it like to be James Bond? I mean, to walk around with people knowing you're Bond?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: But you get sort of used to it after you have said, "my name is Bond, James Bond" 400 times.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Do people make you still say that?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: Oh, yes, always.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Everywhere you go?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: Every interview.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: How many women do you think you have seduced because you played James Bond in the last 50 years?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: Been married four times. (LAUGHTER]

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: The mere fact you've been married four times, Sir Roger, suggests that --

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: You had a way with the ladies over the years.

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: Well, I've -- I'm very -- I find it very difficult to say no.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: You also married very volatile women. It seemed like every time you got out of the fire, you put yourself straight back into the frying pan

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: It's not quite true. It's just that I am one of those people that I don't argue. It annoys, I think, ladies, if you don't answer back.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: So you always just this nice, calm figure?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: I try to be. Inside, I'm churning. I have to take Nexium every morning for my stomach.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Have you been what British people would describe as a bit of a naughty boy over the years, would you say?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: Depends what the definition of naughty is.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: What would your definition be?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: I suppose getting drunk, falling over and waking up in strange hotel rooms. With people you wonder who they are?

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Do you have any regrets in your 85 years?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: I regret I can't start them all again.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Really? I always get the feeling with you -- you seem really -- a very self-aware man who has really enjoyed his life. For all the good and bad stuff that's happened, primarily you've enjoyed your life.

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: I've been terribly lucky. And I don't know why. Why I should have been selected to be -- have sort of the luck shine upon them. But I always kept working. I sort of had some many happy moments.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: The book is fascinating and it goes back over the 50 years of Bond movies. Are you surprised that the Bond franchise is still so successful?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: You didn't hold that book up high enough.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Sorry, Sir Roger. There we are.

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: "Bond on Bond."

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Are you surprised that it still -- I mean, even more successful than it was 50 years ago?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: No, not really. Because I know that they've never cheated the audiences. They spend the money, put it on the screen. And in the days when Bond started, you must remember, the travel was very expensive. So people didn't go to all those places. They would see it along the screen, transported into a little bit of heaven, if you like. But they saw things they didn't see in their everyday life. And then you mix that up with beautiful girls, a great adventure, the old hero story, the white knight.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: We just heard the presidential election here. Did you take much interest in that?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: An election, really? Well, of course, we are always curious.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: You a fan of Barack Obama?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: I'm not going to answer anything political.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Really?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: Because I work with UNICEF and you're not allowed with the United Nations.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: I think whatever you think of Obama domestically in America, and obviously the opinion is divided, and half the country nearly in the popular vote didn't vote for him, but I think abroad Obama has definitely restored a lot of America's reputation. That's the sense I get. Do you feel that when you travel the world?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: Yes, I think that he, like Reagan, makes an American proud to be an American.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Yes. I totally agree. If I could give you five minutes back of your entire life, and it can't involve marriage or children to relive, the greatest moment of your life, what would you choose?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: I suppose being with my parents when I did something that was worthwhile.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Getting their love and respect?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: What do you think they would have made of the way you ended up?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: Well, my mother would be very grateful, because she always said, don't you think you should get a regular job, son?

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Your dad was a policeman. What would he have made of it?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: He was very happy. If it hadn't been for them, I couldn't have been an actor. They had to support me while I was studying. Studying, you know, when I was abroad, during the war.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: That's basically been the story of your life ever since, isn't it, Sir Roger?

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: Outnumbered.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Well, I can talk to you all day, as you know. It's been a fascinating encounter. Is the way I'd best describe this. "Bond on Bond, Reflections on 50 Years of James Bond Movies." The great Sir Roger Moore. Flying the flag for Britain around the world, with UNICEF and everything else. It's been a real honor.

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: Thank you so much.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Lovely to see you.

transcript.speaker: Moore
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Roger Moore, a true legend. And we'll be right back.
